xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: This research has been supported by the Ratchadaphiseksomphot Endowment Fund of Chulalongkorn University ( RES560530203-AM ) and Rachadapisek Sompote Fund for Postdoctoral Fellowship, Chulalongkorn University. This work has partially been supported by the Nanotechnology Center (NANOTEC), Ministry of Science and Technology , Thailand, through its program of Center of Excellence Network.

organization.$: Laboratory of Advanced Polymers and Nanomaterials
School of Materials Science and Engineering and Center of Excellence for Innovation in Chemistry
NANOTEC-MU Excellence Center on Intelligent Materials and Systems

head.citation-title: Utilization of polydiacetylene/zinc oxide nanocomposites to detect and differentiate organic bases in various media
head.abstracts: © 2016 The Korean Society of Industrial and Engineering ChemistryPolydiacetylene/zinc oxide (PDA/ZnO) nanocomposites are demonstrated as colorimetric sensors for organic bases. Influence of stimuli structure on the color-transition behaviors is investigated. Addition of methylamine, ethylamine, butylamine and pentylamine into pure PDAs with different alkyl chain length induces blue-to-red transition at the same concentration. Interestingly, for PDA/ZnO, it shows an ability to differentiate these alkylamines. The detecting concentration and the ability to differentiate the alkylamines can be controlled by adjusting the alkyl chain length of PDA/ZnO. Moreover, PDA/ZnO-embedded paper is successfully fabricated and used to detect alkylamines in different media. Results extend the utilization of PDA-based materials in sensing technologies.

translated-sourcetitle.$: Journal of Industrial and Engineering Chemistry

publisher.publishername: Korean Society of Industrial Engineering Chemistry

source.sourcetitle: Journal of Industrial and Engineering Chemistry

coredata.dc:description: Polydiacetylene/zinc oxide (PDA/ZnO) nanocomposites are demonstrated as colorimetric sensors for organic bases. Influence of stimuli structure on the color-transition behaviors is investigated. Addition of methylamine, ethylamine, butylamine and pentylamine into pure PDAs with different alkyl chain length induces blue-to-red transition at the same concentration. Interestingly, for PDA/ZnO, it shows an ability to differentiate these alkylamines. The detecting concentration and the ability to differentiate the alkylamines can be controlled by adjusting the alkyl chain length of PDA/ZnO. Moreover, PDA/ZnO-embedded paper is successfully fabricated and used to detect alkylamines in different media. Results extend the utilization of PDA-based materials in sensing technologies.
